I'm a pessimist about ET intelligent life. When I assign values to the variable in the Drake Equation I end up with less than 1 radio transmitting civilisation per galaxy. Other people will arrive at millions. The values assign depend mostly on the temperament of the person. Only now are we getting some good data to assign to the P variable of the Drake Equation (number of planets) but the other variables are guesstimates which is to say they are emotimates.
The big problem for me is the L variable (longevity) to which I typically assign a lower number than most other people. My hunch is fast of population and energy use leads to a quick burn out like a fire and I suspect there is not enough fuel in each forest to allow the fire to "jump forests". Enrico Fermi was an uber optimist and expected very quick contact with ET, within a decade. Disappointed when this did not happen he asked the question which is now known as thee Fermi Paradox.
Maybe to these aliens the speed of light is just a tap on the gas.

The origin of life was fast (on a geologic time scale, if not on a human one). Fast is not the same as easy. If you've got a match, it can burst into flame very quickly. But you can't infer from that, if you look at a forest, that most of the twigs are matches. It's just not sound reasoning.

Maybe Earth is special, and maybe it isn't. Maybe you need a giant collision at just the right angle, to produce a giant moon and leave just the right mix of elements in the mantle, in order for life to ever begin. Maybe you don't. The fact that it was relatively quick doesn't tell us which.

LOL. I hope you people don't think these videos are anything but stories and fairytales, because they aren't. From the stories we've been told about heliocentric theory, we can easily disprove it. Old Phil did a wonderful job in a previous video explaining moon phases. Even though it's completely obvious and observable by everyone on Earth, nice job. Let's examine how heliocentric theory explains (or rather can't explain) the moon's phases. Helio theory says the Earth orbits the sun at 67,000 MPH. It says the moon orbits the Earth at 2,288 MPH, giving the moon an actual speed of 69,288 MPH. As the moon orbits the Earth its direction of travel changes relative to that of the Earth's orbit around the sun. This means while the moon may indeed have a relative speed of 2,288 MPH while traveling the same direction as the Earth, relative motion states that changes exponentially during the course of its orbit. Consistent with relative motion theory, when the moon travels perpendicular to the Earth's orbit, observers on Earth would no longer see a relative speed of 2,288 MPH, but the actual speed of the moon 69,288 MPH. But wait, there's more. When the moon and Earth orbits are in opposite directions, the relative speed is moon (69,288 MPH) + Earth (67,000 MPH) = 136,288 MPH! Almost 60x FASTER than when the moon is on the other side of the Earth traveling in the same direction as Earth. This means the new moon phase and phases immediately preceding and following it would all be over in half a day if the moon orbits the Earth in a month! LOL. That doesn't happen. As Phil indicates in his other video, all the moon phases are present for an equal amount of time. Gee Phil, how is this possible if heliocentrism is correct? Can't wait for your next video explaining this.

It's becoming popular for people in the scientific community to say that the conditions to create life must be common, or that starting life must be easy in some way.

I think it's always worth pointing out - we have no idea what the conditions for creating life are. We don't know how it started here. And we tend to think that all life here on Earth is a single, related strain. So even here, a place we think is ideal for life and has been around for billions of years, we only know of life starting one time.
We know some of the factors that our life needs to continue to exist, but we don't actually know what factors life needs to start. It may be common. It may be extremely rare. We don't know the mechanistic explanation of how it starts, and we have exactly one data point to work with... so we still can't give a reasonable statistical chance for any conclusion about life in the universe.

Any scientifically literate person who is honest with themselves will realize that this is the case. Every YouTube video that tells you it's likely that there's plenty of life in the galaxy is BSing you, or themselves, or both.

UFO is an interesting tatuology, given that it is in itself an identification. A UFO is a UFO right up until we say it is, at which point it becomes a FO!

Best thing to do if someone asks you if you believe in UFOs is throw something past their head real fast ;)

If so many life forms spontaneously have popped up, do we still observe that happening? If not, why? Has every possible form already appeared?

Isn't it arrogant to think life in other parts of the universe wouldn't be so advanced that we would be able to detect their signals sent millions or billions of years ago?

If we are evolved from "apes" shouldn't there be transitional fossils much more than dinosaur fossils? Wouldn't they be easily found everywhere?

There seems to be a lot of holes in commonly accepted scientific thought. Considering how little we know of what is to be known I think we should be hesitant to declare certain things as fact.

For example, while it certainly appears the universe is roughly 14 billion years old, it could be much less or much more. While spontaneous life resulting from elements left alone for a long enough time to eventually form thoughts and emotions may be the conclusion of mathematical equations, the conclusion seems preposterous to me.

Science is wonderful but, as Dirty Harry said, "A man's got to know his limitations." (I know mine. My science education is very limited but, some of the conclusions scientist make seem ridiculous. PJ O'Rourke once described the 1911 Encyclopedia Britannica. He said the prevailing scientists of that day were very smug and confident in their conclusions which we now know to be laughable.)

Why do people think that a civilisation has to use massive radio-transmitters at some point? I mean, we don't use them any-more - we use lasers and optic fibers today - radio-wave transmission is used only locally. Only reason why we used powerful radios in the first place is because we perfected other telecommunication technologies later. The radio time-window of humanity was only about 100years and it's a stupid assumption to make, that an arbitrary civilisation would even have one.

On the SETI listening to radio waves; something I thought of a while back is it's ENTIRELY likely that if other races had discovered radio and had been using it, the signals may have been skewed long long ago.

Think about it; what's one of the biggest ways to mess with radio waves: magnets. Per the magnetar episode, one quake on a magnetar was strong enough to disable all the man made satellites in orbit back in the 80s. Something THAT powerful could have easily obliterated any radio waves we could have detected.

I feel like this is the big X factor missing when evaluating why we haven't heard aliens.

Heck, at this point, we have enough ideas to fathom that there are better communication methods out there. Quantum Intangible, for instance, is being heavily researched as a method to have much, much, much greater range on our telephony communication. Thats just one method that would leave radio in the dust.

DON'T FORGET PLUTO! We have lots of data from New Horizon now. And you skipped over it to wait for the data, remember?

...and you could mention the recently discovered planet X in the passing.

Did you know? Exoplanets is a word made up from 2 Greek words!
Exo + planets.
Exo = Έξω (in Greek) means "Outside" [Ε=Έ χ=ξ ο=ω]
Planets = Πλανήτες (in Greek) means "Those who wander" [P=Π l=λ a=α n=ν et=ήτε s=ς] ~ or "the wanderers"
So exoplanets means "Far away wanderers" / Or in other words, spheres that wander aroud far away

It's pretty much pointless to look for alien signals beyond a couple thousand light years.
For example, a transmission of a single bit from 1500 ly distance requires in order of 10^15 Joules of energy. And this have to be a coherent signal which can be filtered out. For example, if a transmitter is a thousand of megawatt, it will take a million seconds for one bit, and its phase has to be corrected for the transmitter planetary rotation and the recipient direction. This means it has to be intended to be received at our star.

There are so few things I consider life changing. This Crash Course series fits squarely within that definition. Now I know, blah blah blah its just a Youtube channel etc. etc. but please hear me out.

Phil, you sparked my imagination from the first episode when you put astronomy into a broader context and had the audacity to imply that even an uneducated simpleton (by any real scientific standard) could be considered an "astronomer" by just looking to the stars with curiosity.

I purchased a set of binoculars and got to see Jupiter's moons for the first time and even harassed you on Twitter to check it out. I was smitten when you responded! I sat for hours with that same pair of binoculars looking at Saturn and no matter what anyone tells me I swore I could see it oval despite my shaky hands! And I just purchased my first telescope to really expand my eye into the sky as I do "crave to understand the sky above me" as you so eloquently put it early last year.

I've taken my nephew to planetariums and grown family bonds by learning more about our solar system - inspired by this series. I even forced my wife to check out Jupiter's moons through the binoculars and even she thought that was so cool! And now I have a son on the way and I can't wait to rewatch this series with him and help foster the same type of curiosity you've instilled in me.

That is the true magic of Crash Course and what you have accomplished here Phil. Thank you so much for your time and effort.

I find it strange that you describe our tech as "primitive". I think it's more likely that we are -- by galactic standards -- highly advanced. In fact, I'm betting that we're very close to the maximum technological development that any industrial civilization can reach before exhausting its resources and declining.

We only got where we are by happenstance. Specifically, the evolutionary history of our planet just happened to produce large quantities of an energy source that is very energy-efficient to extract. But that efficiency is declining. Even if we manage to transition to a global post-carbon civilization -- and it's by no means certain that we will -- we will likely see peak energy production within our lifetimes, simply because there is no universally-available technology we know of that can match oil in efficiency.

There are probably lots of intelligent species out there. But how many of them are lucky enough to have the kind of biological inheritance that we did? How many of them never get to develop the kind of heavy industry necessary to make nukes, let alone broadcast radio signals stronger than anything we are capable of?

Regardless, this was a really good series.

Personally, I think intelligent life is a short lived phenomenon in a planet's evolution. It may exist for a million years or so and a few thousand in a time of high tech like ours because it over consumes the planet and reverts back to a dark age. Hence why it appears intelligent life doesn't seem to exist elsewhere in the Galaxy. Intelligent life is probably very unlikely to exist simultaneously in one galaxy. I think it's more likely to find a planet that resembles earth in the past, mostly precambrian. But we might find a planet with things that resemble shellfish, dinosaurs, coal swamps with giant insects, a dry climate planet with a super continent with conifer and sail fin reptiles as each of those environments were chapters of Earth's history and lasted a long time. Everyone thinks to human centrically about the whole thing.

Phil. Thanks so much for your knowledge, curiosity and enthusiasm in tackling this course. It was a bit to get into at first, but this is by far the most unbiased and interesting CC yet. Pure science and information through and through. You never pushed your personal beliefs and ideology on anyone; that is highly unusual in the CC library and truly a testament to your character. Thanks for making it that way.

My one question to you is this:

Why are we as humans (especially we humans in a post-modern, scientific and liberal culture) comfortable with, or at least curious about, the idea of NATURE but not the idea of a deity?

When I say NATURE I refer to the idea, that even you have alluded to, where the cosmos are an impersonal, all powerful force that rules our every moment and entire lives with physical laws that we are only now just beginning to understand we have know so little about. We say things like "Nature is much smarter than us". We personify the cosmos and give them a place of ruling over us. We even begin to worship them, submitting to them out of reverence and awe.

Why are we comfortable with this concept but not the idea of a personified and knowable deity that we can actually interact with? How can we have we thrown the god(s) out with the power of science, only to end this series off with the final few paragraphs you did?

I'm just a bit puzzled is all. It's like we think we are so much better than our forefathers for believing in and worshiping a higher power (how silly is that right?), but yet here we find ourselves realizing that our true place in the universe is to be ruled by it. We realize that the universe is the ultimate authority in our existence and worthy of our pursuit, knowledge and resources, though we know for certain that we will never fully understand all of it. How is this any different than the most basic tenants of most major religions?

What are your personal thoughts on this?

But.. but what if we are the first aliens having access to communication? What if we are actually the first aliens exploring the universe? Waiting for thousands of other planets (eggs) to breed and revolute. The universe is amazing and not knowing drives me crazy ;)

The failure to find any extraterrestrial civilizations in the observable universe implies the possibility something is wrong with one or more of the arguments from various scientific disciplines that the appearance of advanced intelligent life is probable; this observation is conceptualized in terms of a "Great Filter" which acts to reduce the great number of sites where intelligent life might arise to the tiny number of intelligent species with advanced civilizations actually observed (currently just one: human). This probability threshold, which could lie behind us (in our past) or in front of us (in our future), might work as a barrier to the evolution of intelligent life, or as a high probability of self-destruction.The main counter-intuitive conclusion of this observation is that the easier it was for life to evolve to our stage, the bleaker our future chances probably are.

Excellent episode, excellent series. I have one thought which I've never really heard before which regards SETI and the Fermi paradox: Why would a much more advanced civilisation broadcast at all? What would they gain from attempting to find other more backward and potentially more hostile life? There's nothing they could gain from meeting us. They wouldn't do it for knowledge, and they wouldn't do it for seeing how rare life is. They would already know how rare it is via unimaginable powerful universal simulations, so what's the need? And that's just if they do exist! Which I don't think they do, simple life yes, civilisations no, or at very most sprinkled between billions of light years. My point is either way there is no benefit for civilisations to ever meet each other, an advanced enough civilisation would logically see there's no benefit, and only potential danger to meet another.
They could easily make a video just about all of the discoveries that have happened since this series started. What we've learned about Pluto alone could be one.

The assumption: "life comes easy" is based upon a single example (earth). Deducting probabilities from a sample size of  1 is kind of pseudoscience. This means that the chances for life getting started are only known to be somewhere between 0 and 1. As long, as we don't have a better understanding of this probability we can not reasonably estimate the overall chances of extraterrestrial life. For example the fact, that we haven't found life anywhere else in the solar system (and Mars is in the habitable zone, although at the outer limits and once had fluid water and was significantly warmer) and that we have not been able to artificially recreate it in the lab, makes it quite likely that abiogenesis might not be AS easy to come by, as you think it is. So to make it short, we currently don't have the slightest idea is abiogenesis is rare or ubiquitous , as long as we are not able to significantly increase the observed and randomized sample size.

We've had radio waves for around a 100 years which is less than a sliver of the 3.8 billion years of life that existed on Earth. We've existed for only 10,00 which is still a tiny fraction. For alien life to communicate with us they must be

1. At the same era of technology (radio waves) who knows if they will become rudimentary soon. We will generously say 1000 year span.
2. Be around the same intelligence which we can generously grant a 1 million year span. Life might always self destruct or ascend to inter-dimensional beings in this span.

So (1000/1 million)*(10,000/3.8 billion)=2.63*10^-6 which is a very, very rough approximation of the probability of communicating with extraterrestrial life. Furthermore, their planets would need to be at the right distance for their light to reach us during our lifetime and humanity's lifetime.

Now I'm not quite sure how many exo-planets fit the bill but this is why I'm still skeptical of ever making contact with aliens at least in my life time.

Do I believe in aliens (defined as life that is not on, and does not originate from, Earth)? Yes. Do I believe they've come to Earth? Nope, if aliens ever came to Earth, we are their descendants (panspermia hypothesis) and even then it's not necessarily more likely than life spontaneously arising on Earth.

Communicating using neutrinos? That sounds like a curious concept, but wouldn't speed be an issue? Neutrinos travel slower than light. Even across distances within our own solar system, light speed quickly becomes the limiting factor and I imagine that if advanced alien civilizations exist, they might want communication to be as swift as possible, especially during space missions. Then again, it's likely that such a civilization would have wormholes or space-bending technology to bypass the speed of light in the first place, if they're investigating other star systems, so I suppose these hypothetical aliens would use something similar for their communications.

Using quantum entanglement is more interesting though, I can imagine a sort of phrasebook situation where the entangled particles are linked such that standard questions and an array of possible answers are prepared in advance, and then you can have instantaneous communication (limited to those pre-programmed questions and answers) between the space party and the planet of origin. I know that's not exactly how quantum entanglement works but I can somewhat see how a space-faring civilization might try to modify it to work.
